clinical_study.brief_title: Comparing Mobilization Techniques for the Hemiplegic Shoulder
clinical_study.official_title: Comparing Mobilization Techniques for the Hemiplegic Shoulder

brief_summary.textblock: One of the main complications after stroke is hemiplegic shoulder pain. It is known that one of the most frequent causes of hemiplegic shoulder pain is a restricted range of motion in the shoulder joint. Therefore, it is necessary to preserve the passive range of motion by using the most optimal mobilization technique. The aim of this study is to compare 2 different techniques in order to document their influence on shoulder range of motion and shoulder pain in stroke patients.

study_design_info.masking_description: Patients do not know what are the intervention techniques or what is the control technique.

primary_outcome.measure: Range of motion of the shoulder using goniometry
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measuring every 4 weeks up to 12 weeks after admission to the study protocol
primary_outcome.description: Range of motion of the shoulder joint is measured using a goniometer

primary_outcome.measure: Shoulder pain using visual analogue scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measuring every 4 weeks up to 12 weeks after admission to the study protocol
primary_outcome.description: Shoulder pain during rest, night and activities by using visual analogue scale (0-10)

secondary_outcome.measure: Spasticity of the shoulder muscles using the Modified Ashworth Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measuring every 4 weeks up to 12 weeks after admission to the study protocol
secondary_outcome.description: Spasticity of upper limb muscles related to the shoulder using Modified Ashworth Scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Trunk Impairment Scale to assess trunk stability
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measuring every 4 weeks up to 12 weeks after admission to the study protocol
secondary_outcome.description: Trunk stability using the Trunk Impairment Scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Fugl-Meyer Assessment - upper limb part to assess voluntary muscle activity
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measuring every 4 weeks up to 12 weeks after admission to the study protocol
secondary_outcome.description: voluntary muscle activity upper limb using the upper limb part of the Fugl-Meyer Scale

arm_group.description: Angular mobilization of the shoulder joint in the frontal plane.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Angular mobilization with soft tissue techniques
arm_group.description: Angular mobilization performed in the scapular plane. Additional soft tissue techniques to eliminate limitations created by tensed muscles in order to perform capsular stretch.

intervention.description: Comparing the effect of angular mobilization in frontal or scapular plane and of providing soft tissue techniques on hemiplegic shoulder range of motion and pain.
intervention.arm_group_label: Angular mobilization with soft tissue techniques

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- First stroke
- Upper limb impairment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Shoulder pain on the hemiplegic side with onset before the stroke
- Surgery at the hemiplegic shoulder
- Active movement possible within the whole range of motion
